trans-unit.source: Expression Trees Explained
trans-unit.target: Expression Trees Explained

trans-unit.source: Previous -- Overview
trans-unit.target: Previous -- Overview

trans-unit.source: An Expression Tree is a data structure that defines code.
trans-unit.target: An Expression Tree is a data structure that defines code.

trans-unit.source: They are based on the same structures that a compiler uses to analyze code and generate the compiled output.
trans-unit.target: They are based on the same structures that a compiler uses to analyze code and generate the compiled output.

trans-unit.source: As you read through this tutorial, you will notice quite a bit of similarity between Expression Trees and the types used in the Roslyn APIs to build [Analyzers and CodeFixes](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn-analyzers).
trans-unit.target: As you read through this tutorial, you will notice quite a bit of similarity between Expression Trees and the types used in the Roslyn APIs to build [Analyzers and CodeFixes](https://github.com/dotnet/roslyn-analyzers).

trans-unit.source: (Analyzers and CodeFixes are NuGet packages that perform static analysis on code and can suggest potential fixes for a developer.) The concepts are similar, and the end result is a data structure that allows examination of the source ode in a meaningful way.
trans-unit.target: (Analyzers and CodeFixes are NuGet packages that perform static analysis on code and can suggest potential fixes for a developer.) The concepts are similar, and the end result is a data structure that allows examination of the source ode in a meaningful way.

trans-unit.source: However, Expression Trees are based on a totally different set of classes and APIs than the Roslyn APIs.
trans-unit.target: However, Expression Trees are based on a totally different set of classes and APIs than the Roslyn APIs.

trans-unit.source: Let's look at a simple example.
trans-unit.target: Let's look at a simple example.

trans-unit.source: Here's a line of code:
trans-unit.target: Here's a line of code:

trans-unit.source: If you were to analyze this as an expression tree, the tree contains several nodes.
trans-unit.target: If you were to analyze this as an expression tree, the tree contains several nodes.

trans-unit.source: The outermost node is a variable declaration statement with assignment (`var sum = 1 + 2;`) That outermost node contains several child nodes: a variable declaration, an assignment operator, and an expression representing the right hand side of the equals sign.
trans-unit.target: The outermost node is a variable declaration statement with assignment (`var sum = 1 + 2;`) That outermost node contains several child nodes: a variable declaration, an assignment operator, and an expression representing the right hand side of the equals sign.

trans-unit.source: That expression is further subdivided into expressions that represent the addition operation, and left and right operands of the addition.
trans-unit.target: That expression is further subdivided into expressions that represent the addition operation, and left and right operands of the addition.

trans-unit.source: Let's drill down a bit more into the expressions that make up the right side of the equals sign.
trans-unit.target: Let's drill down a bit more into the expressions that make up the right side of the equals sign.

trans-unit.source: The expression is `1 + 2`.
trans-unit.target: The expression is `1 + 2`.

trans-unit.source: That's a binary expression.
trans-unit.target: That's a binary expression.

trans-unit.source: More specifically, it's a binary addition expression.
trans-unit.target: More specifically, it's a binary addition expression.

trans-unit.source: A binary addition expression has two children, representing the left and right nodes of the addition expression.
trans-unit.target: A binary addition expression has two children, representing the left and right nodes of the addition expression.

trans-unit.source: Here, both nodes are constant expressions: The left operand is the value `1`, and the right operand is the value `2`.
trans-unit.target: Here, both nodes are constant expressions: The left operand is the value `1`, and the right operand is the value `2`.

trans-unit.source: Visually, the entire statement is a tree: You could start at the root node, and travel to each node in the tree to see the code that makes up the statement:
trans-unit.target: Visually, the entire statement is a tree: You could start at the root node, and travel to each node in the tree to see the code that makes up the statement:

trans-unit.source: Variable declaration statement with assignment (`var sum = 1 + 2;`)
trans-unit.target: Variable declaration statement with assignment (`var sum = 1 + 2;`)

trans-unit.source: Implicit variable type declaration (`var sum`)
trans-unit.target: Implicit variable type declaration (`var sum`)

trans-unit.source: Implicit var keyword (`var`)
trans-unit.target: Implicit var keyword (`var`)

trans-unit.source: Variable name declaration (`sum`)
trans-unit.target: Variable name declaration (`sum`)

trans-unit.source: Assignment operator (`=`)
trans-unit.target: Assignment operator (`=`)

trans-unit.source: Binary addition expression (`1 + 2`)
trans-unit.target: Binary addition expression (`1 + 2`)

trans-unit.source: Left operand (`1`)
trans-unit.target: Left operand (`1`)

trans-unit.source: Addition operator (`+`)
trans-unit.target: Addition operator (`+`)

trans-unit.source: Right operand (`2`)
trans-unit.target: Right operand (`2`)

trans-unit.source: This may look complicated, but it is very powerful.
trans-unit.target: This may look complicated, but it is very powerful.

trans-unit.source: Following the same process, you can decompose much more complicated expressions.
trans-unit.target: Following the same process, you can decompose much more complicated expressions.

trans-unit.source: Consider this expression:
trans-unit.target: Consider this expression:

trans-unit.source: The expression above is also a variable declaration with an assignment.
trans-unit.target: The expression above is also a variable declaration with an assignment.

trans-unit.source: In this instance, the right hand side of the assignment is a much more complicated tree.
trans-unit.target: In this instance, the right hand side of the assignment is a much more complicated tree.

trans-unit.source: I'm not going to decompose this expression, but consider what the different nodes might be.
trans-unit.target: I'm not going to decompose this expression, but consider what the different nodes might be.

trans-unit.source: There are method calls using the current object as a receiver, one that has an explicit `this` receiver, one that does not.
trans-unit.target: There are method calls using the current object as a receiver, one that has an explicit `this` receiver, one that does not.

trans-unit.source: There are method calls using other receiver objects, there are constant arguments of different types.
trans-unit.target: There are method calls using other receiver objects, there are constant arguments of different types.

trans-unit.source: And finally, there is a binary addition operator.
trans-unit.target: And finally, there is a binary addition operator.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the return type of `SecretSauceFunction()` or `MoreSecretSauce()`, that binary addition operator may be a method call to an overridden addition operator, resolving to a static method call to the binary addition operator defined for a class.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the return type of `SecretSauceFunction()` or `MoreSecretSauce()`, that binary addition operator may be a method call to an overridden addition operator, resolving to a static method call to the binary addition operator defined for a class.

trans-unit.source: Despite this perceived complexity, the expression above creates a tree structure that can be navigated as easily as the first sample.
trans-unit.target: Despite this perceived complexity, the expression above creates a tree structure that can be navigated as easily as the first sample.

trans-unit.source: You can keep traversing child nodes to find leaf nodes in the expression.
trans-unit.target: You can keep traversing child nodes to find leaf nodes in the expression.

trans-unit.source: Parent nodes will have references to their children, and each node has a property that describes what kind of node it is.
trans-unit.target: Parent nodes will have references to their children, and each node has a property that describes what kind of node it is.

trans-unit.source: The structure of an expression tree is very consistent.
trans-unit.target: The structure of an expression tree is very consistent.

trans-unit.source: Once you've learned the basics, you can understand even the most complex code when it is represented as an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: Once you've learned the basics, you can understand even the most complex code when it is represented as an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: The elegance in the data structure explains how the C# compiler can analyze the most complex C# programs and create proper output from that complicated source code.
trans-unit.target: The elegance in the data structure explains how the C# compiler can analyze the most complex C# programs and create proper output from that complicated source code.

trans-unit.source: Once you become familiar with the structure of expression trees, you will find that knowledge you've gained quickly enables you to work with many more and more advanced scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Once you become familiar with the structure of expression trees, you will find that knowledge you've gained quickly enables you to work with many more and more advanced scenarios.

trans-unit.source: There is incredible power to expression trees.
trans-unit.target: There is incredible power to expression trees.

trans-unit.source: In addition to translating algorithms to execute in other environments, expression trees can be used to make it easier to write algorithms that inspect code before executing it.
trans-unit.target: In addition to translating algorithms to execute in other environments, expression trees can be used to make it easier to write algorithms that inspect code before executing it.

trans-unit.source: You can write a method whose arguments are expressions and then examine those expressions before executing the code.
trans-unit.target: You can write a method whose arguments are expressions and then examine those expressions before executing the code.

trans-unit.source: The Expression Tree is a full representation of the code: you can see values of any sub-expression.
trans-unit.target: The Expression Tree is a full representation of the code: you can see values of any sub-expression.

trans-unit.source: You can see method and property names.
trans-unit.target: You can see method and property names.

trans-unit.source: You can see the value of any constant expressions.
trans-unit.target: You can see the value of any constant expressions.

trans-unit.source: You can also convert an expression tree into an executable delegate, and execute the code.
trans-unit.target: You can also convert an expression tree into an executable delegate, and execute the code.

trans-unit.source: The APIs for Expression Trees enable you to create trees that represent almost any valid code construct.
trans-unit.target: The APIs for Expression Trees enable you to create trees that represent almost any valid code construct.

trans-unit.source: However, to keep things as simple as possible, some C# idioms cannot be created in an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: However, to keep things as simple as possible, some C# idioms cannot be created in an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: One example is asynchronous expressions (using the `async` and `await` keywords).
trans-unit.target: One example is asynchronous expressions (using the `async` and `await` keywords).

trans-unit.source: If your needs require asynchronous algorithms, you would need to manipulate the `Task` objects directly, rather than rely on the compiler support.
trans-unit.target: If your needs require asynchronous algorithms, you would need to manipulate the `Task` objects directly, rather than rely on the compiler support.

trans-unit.source: Another is in creating loops.
trans-unit.target: Another is in creating loops.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you create these by using `for`, `foreach`, `while` or `do` loops.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you create these by using `for`, `foreach`, `while` or `do` loops.

trans-unit.source: As you'll see [later in this series](expression-trees-building.md), the APIs for expression trees support a single loop expression, with `break` and `continue` expressions that control repeating the loop.
trans-unit.target: As you'll see [later in this series](expression-trees-building.md), the APIs for expression trees support a single loop expression, with `break` and `continue` expressions that control repeating the loop.

trans-unit.source: The one thing you can't do is modify an expression tree.
trans-unit.target: The one thing you can't do is modify an expression tree.

trans-unit.source: Expression Trees are immutable data structures.
trans-unit.target: Expression Trees are immutable data structures.

trans-unit.source: If you want to mutate (change) an expression tree, you must create a new tree that is a copy of the original, but with your desired changes.
trans-unit.target: If you want to mutate (change) an expression tree, you must create a new tree that is a copy of the original, but with your desired changes.

trans-unit.source: Next -- Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees
trans-unit.target: Next -- Framework Types Supporting Expression Trees
